rounds.response:
I have A♦ 9♠ in the big-blind position. I’m facing a single 20-chip raise (to 20 total) from the small blind, so I need to call 10 more chips to see the flop. A9o is a decent but not premium holding, and closing the action heads-up with position post-flop makes calling the small additional bet the best choice.

[Call]

rounds.response:
I have A♦ 9♠ and the flop comes 2♠ 8♠ 4♠ – three spades on a low, uncoordinated board. 

Observation:
- I do not have a spade in my hand, so I do not hold even a single flush draw card.
- My two cards give me only an over-card (Ace) and a medium kicker (9) with no back-door straight draws worth mentioning.
- Continuation betting into this texture when out of position and without equity is usually a losing play long-term; if I’m called I’ll often be behind any made flush or any one-spade hand with an over-card.
- Checking gives me the chance to see the turn for free and preserves chips for better spots.

[Check]
